IntroQuick3
public class Quick3 extends Quick
Quick Sort 3-Way in simple QuickSort algorithm, we select an element as pivot, partition the array around a pivot and recur for subarrays on the left and right of the pivot. Simple Quick Sort, we fix only one 4 and recursively process remaining occurrences. The idea of 3 way Quick Sort is to process all occurrences of the pivot

  • Constructor Details

    • Quick3

      public Quick3()
      Quick Sort 3-Way:
      Quick Sort 3-Way in simple QuickSort algorithm, we select an element as pivot, partition the array around a pivot and recur for subarrays on the left and right of the pivot. Simple Quick Sort, we fix only one 4 and recursively process remaining occurrences. The idea of 3 way Quick Sort is to process all occurrences of the pivot.

      Example:
      1. Choose a pivot element from the array. This can be done in various ways, such as selecting the left, right element.
      2. Partition the array into two sub-arrays: one with elements less than the pivot and another with elements greater than the pivot. The pivot should be in its final sorted position.
      3. Recursively apply the above steps to the sub-arrays, until the entire array is sorted.
      4. The base case of the recursion is when a sub-array has fewer than two elements, in which case it is already considered sorted.
      Note:
      Quicksort has an average-case time complexity of O(n log(n)) and performs well in practice. It is widely used and is considered one of the fastest general-purpose sorting algorithms. The average number of recursive calls made to the quicksort function is log(n), and every time the function is called we are traversing the given array/list which requires O(N) time. Thus, the total time complexity is O(n log(n)).

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(log(n))
      Stability: No
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQQuick3
      • IntroQuick3

    • quick3Inc

      protected void quick3Inc(Comparable[] array)
      quick3Inc that implements the Quick Sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in ascending order.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and the left is 0 and right is (array.length - 1) indices specifying the portion of the array to be sorted.
      • The method first checks if the left index is greater than or equal to the right index. If so, it means the portion of the array is empty or contains only one element, and no further sorting is required. In such cases, the method returns.
      • If there are more than one elements in the portion, the method proceeds with the sorting process.
      • The variables i and j are set to left and right, respectively, representing the boundaries of the partition.
      • The partition3Inc method is called to partition the array into three parts using the three-way partitioning technique.
      • After the partitioning, the array is divided into three parts: elements less than the pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements greater than the pivot.
      • The method recursively calls itself to sort the left and right partitions separately.
      • The first recursive call, quickInc(array, left, i), sorts the left partition from left to i.
      • The second recursive call, quickInc(array, j, right), sorts the right partition from j to right.
      • The sorting process continues recursively until the entire array is sorted.
      quick3Inc method implements the Quick Sort algorithm to sort the given array of Comparable objects in ascending order. It performs a three-way partitioning and recursively sorts the left and right partitions until the entire array is sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.

    • quick3Dec

      protected void quick3Dec(Comparable[] array)

      • The method first checks if the left index is greater than or equal to the right index. If so, it means the portion of the array is empty or contains only one element, and no further sorting is required. In such cases, the method returns.
      • If there are more than one elements in the portion, the method proceeds with the sorting process.
      • The variables i and j are set to left and right, respectively, representing the boundaries of the partition.
      • The partition3Dec method is called to partition the array into three parts using the three-way partitioning technique.
      • After the partitioning, the array is divided into three parts: elements less than the pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements greater than the pivot.

    • quick3Inc

      protected void quick3Inc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      quick3Inc that implements the Quick Sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in ascending order.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and the left and right indices specifying the portion of the array to be sorted.
      • The method first checks if the left index is greater than or equal to the right index. If so, it means the portion of the array is empty or contains only one element, and no further sorting is required. In such cases, the method returns.
      • If there are more than one elements in the portion, the method proceeds with the sorting process.
      • The variables i and j are set to left and right, respectively, representing the boundaries of the partition.
      • The partition3Inc method is called to partition the array into three parts using the three-way partitioning technique.
      • After the partitioning, the array is divided into three parts: elements less than the pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements greater than the pivot.
      • The method recursively calls itself to sort the left and right partitions separately.
      • The first recursive call, quickInc(array, left, i), sorts the left partition from left to i.
      • The second recursive call, quickInc(array, j, right), sorts the right partition from j to right.
      • The sorting process continues recursively until the entire array is sorted.

      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.

    • partition3Inc

      protected void partition3Inc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      partition3Inc that partitions an array of Comparable objects into three parts: elements less than a pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements greater than the pivot. The partitioning is done in-place.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and the left and right indices specifying the portion of the array to be partitioned.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method first checks if the portion of the array to be partitioned has one or zero elements. If so, it performs a simple check to ensure that the elements are in the correct order, swaps them if necessary, and sets i to left and j to right.
      • If the portion has more than one element, the method proceeds to perform a three-way partition using the pivot element.
      • The mid variable is initialized with the value of left. This variable represents the current index being considered during the partitioning process.
      • The pivot element is chosen as the element at index right.
      • A while loop is used to iterate from left to right, comparing each element with the pivot and performing the necessary swaps to achieve the three-way partition.
      • If the element at index mid is less than the pivot, it is swapped with the element at index left. left and mid are then incremented to move to the next elements.
      • If the element at index mid is equal to the pivot, mid is incremented to move to the next element without performing any swaps.
      • If the element at index mid is greater than the pivot, it is swapped with the element at index right. right is decremented to move to the next element.
      • After the while loop completes, the array is partitioned into three parts: elements less than the pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements greater than the pivot.
      • The variable i is set to (left - 1) to represent the index of the last element in the left partition.
      • The variable j is set to mid to represent the index where the middle partition begins.
      partition3Inc method partitions the given array of Comparable objects into three parts: elements less than the pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements greater than the pivot. It uses the last element as the pivot and performs swaps to achieve the partitioning. The indices i and j are updated to represent the boundaries of the partitions.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • partition3Dec

      protected void partition3Dec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      partition3Dec that partitions an array of Comparable objects into three parts: elements less than a pivot, elements equal to the pivot, and elements smaller than the pivot. The partitioning is done in-place.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and the left and right indices specifying the portion of the array to be partitioned.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.

      • The pivot element is chosen as the element at index right.

It uses the last element as the pivot and performs swaps to achieve the partitioning. The indices i and j are updated to represent the boundaries of the partitions.
